Shepherd’s Pie: 1 Boil the potatoes: Place the peeled and quartered potatoes in medium sized pot. Cover with at least an inch of cold water. Add a teaspoon of salt. Bring to a boil
2 Sauté vegetables: While the potatoes are cooking
column1: melt 4 tablespoons of the butter in a large sauté pan on medium heat. Add the chopped onions and cook until tender
add them according to their cooking time. Carrots should be cooked with the onions
column2: because they take as long to cook as the onions do.

Shepherd’s Pie: If you are including peas or corn
column1: add them toward the end of the cooking of the onions
column2: or after the meat starts to cook
column3: as they take very little cooking time.

column1: then Worcestershire sauce and broth: Add ground beef to the pan with the onions and vegetables. Cook until no longer pink. Season with salt and pepper.

Shepherd’s Pie: Add the Worcestershire sauce and beef broth. Bring the broth to a simmer and reduce heat to low. Cook uncovered for 10 minutes
column1: adding more beef broth if necessary to keep the meat from drying out.

Shepherd’s Pie: 4 Mash the cooked potatoes: When the potatoes are done cooking (a fork can easily pierce)
column1: remove them from the pot and place them in a bowl with the remaining 4 Tbsp of butter. Mash with a fork or potato masher
column2: and season with salt and pepper to taste.

Shepherd’s Pie: 5 Layer the meat mixture and mashed potatoes in a casserole dish: Preheat oven to 400°F. Spread the beef
column2: and vegetables (if using) in an even layer in a large baking dish (8x13 casserole).

Shepherd’s Pie: Spread the mashed potatoes over the top of the ground beef. Rough up the surface of the mashed potatoes with a fork so there are peaks that will get well browned. You can even use a fork to make creative designs in the mashed potatoes.
6 Bake in oven: Place in a 400°F oven and cook until browned and bubbling
column2: broil for the last few minutes to help the surface of the mashed potatoes brown.

Shepherd’s Pie: Sprinkle grated cheddar cheese over the top of the mashed potatoes before baking.
